item.title: Becoming Steve Jobs
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: Steve couldn’t distinguish between the extraneous in the critical. As CEO of a fledgling company, that was his key responsibility. At NeXT, he utterly failed to do this.

item.title: Becoming Steve Jobs Page 28
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: Steve innately understood from early age that the right words and stories could help him win the attention he needed to get what he wanted.

item.title: Becoming Steve Jobs
item.author: Kyle Tress

item.title: Michael Jackson Inc Loc 1981
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: When working on any project, work with the best people in the business, the best people in the world — expertise in every field of endeavors, the best chemistry, the best unity— and work in secrecy. And when it’s least expected, hit everybody between the eyes with the phenomenal, the most powerful, unexpected project. Then it becomes historical because you have a perfect gem. But strive for excellence and perfection in everything. Study the greats and become greater— in secrecy.

item.title: Michael Jackson, Inc
item.author: Kyle Tress

item.title: The life changing magic of tidying up page 14
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: If you put your house in order in one fell swoop, you will have tidied up in one fell swoop. (In Japanese, the term is ikki ni , or “in one go.”)

item.title: A Guide to the Good Life - page 256
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: I have become fully aware of the extent to which anger has a life of its own within me. It can lie dormant, like a virus, only to revive and make me miserable when I least expect it.

item.title: A Guide to the Good Life - page 261
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: I like to engage in activities, such as competitive rowing, that give me butterflies simply so I can practice dealing with them.

item.title: A Guide to the Good Life - page 203
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: Socrates was, Epictetus reminds us, “tolerant of being overlooked”, and those practicing Stoicism should likewise be tolerant.

item.title: A Guide to the Good Life - page 161
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: In particular, says Seneca, we need to remember that in some case, the person at whom we are angry in fact helped us; in such cases, what angers us is that he didn’t help us more.

item.title: A Guide to the Good Life
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: This book is a terrific introduction to modern Stoic thought. When we hear the word stoic, we often think of a person who is devoid of emotion. But as Irvine explains, our modern interpretation of the stoic is not inline with the classical definition.

item.title: How should I prepare for Skeleton School?
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: There is no preparation necessary for Skeleton School. You don’t need to learn how to drive beforehand – you can’t. You can only learn that aspect of the sport through experience, which comes with taking runs down the track. Skeleton School is mostly an opportunity to see if you really enjoy the sport. It looks fun on TV, but there have been many people who thought the same thing only to arrive in Lake Placid, take a run, and leave that same day never to return. Just show up, listen to the coaches, and see if you like it.
